metadata.title: Multi-objective Maximization of Monotone Submodular Functions with Cardinality Constraint
metadata.author: Rajan Udwani
metadata.abstract: We consider the problem of multi-objective maximization of monotone submodular functions subject to cardinality constraint, often formulated as max|A|=k mini∈{1,...,m} fi(A). While it is widely known that greedy methods work well for a single objective, the problem becomes much harder with multiple objectives. In fact, Krause et al. (2008) showed that when the number of objectives m grows as the cardinality k i.e., m = Ω(k), the problem is inapproximable (unless

highlights: Several well known objectives in combinatorial optimization exhibit two common properties: the marginal value of any given element is non-negative and it decreases as more and more elements are selected
To simplify the description we focus on cardinality constraint, even though it is designed more generally for matroid constraint
key_statements: Several well known objectives in combinatorial optimization exhibit two common properties: the marginal value of any given element is non-negative and it decreases as more and more elements are selected
To simplify the description we focus on cardinality constraint, even though it is designed more generally for matroid constraint
summary: Several well known objectives in combinatorial optimization exhibit two common properties: the marginal value of any given element is non-negative and it decreases as more and more elements are selected.

The problem of maximizing a monotone submodular function subject to a cardinality constraint, P0 := max f (A), A⊆N,|A|≤k goes back to the work of [NWF78, NW78], where they showed that the greedy algorithm gives a guarantee of (1 − 1/e) and this is best possible in the value-oracle model.

For the more general problem maxA∈I f (A), where I is the collection of independent sets of a matroid; [CCPV11, Von08] in a breakthrough, achieved a (1−1/e) approximation by maximizing the multilinear extension of submodular functions, followed by suitable rounding.
For the special case of cardinality constraint, [OSU18] recently showed that the greedy algorithm can be generalized to achieve a deterministic 1 − 1/e − approximation for the
To the best of our knowledge, when m = o(k) no constant factor approximation algorithms or inapproximability results were known prior to this work.
We show three algorithmic results with asymptotic approximation guarantees for m = o(k).

Linear functions and constraints have been the primary setting of interest in these works, but recent applications have shown its usefulness when considering non-linear and in particular submodular objectives ([AG12, CJV15]).

Since the guarantees we present are asymptotic and technically converge to the constant factors indicated as k becomes large, in Section 4 we test the performance of a heuristic closely inspired by our MWU based algorithm on Kronecker graphs [LCK+10] of various sizes and find improved performance over previous heuristics even for small k and large m.

[NWF78, NW78] showed that the natural greedy algorithm for P0 summarized as, starting with ∅, at each step add to the current set an element which adds the maximum marginal value until k elements are chosen, achieves a guarantee of 1 − 1/e for P0 and that this is best possible.
Fix some algorithm A for P0 with guarantee α, and let A(f, k) denote the set it outputs given monotone submodular function f and cardinality constraint k as input.
Their application differs from Algorithm 2 only in minor details, but unlike our result they give a bi-criterion approximation where the output is a set
), if we of A(.), T times, leading to an use the thresholding algorithm upper bound in [BV14] in the approximation guarantee).
Note that indexing elements in order they are picked by the greedy algorithm doesn’t suffice since there are many functions and we need to balance values amongst all.
headline: We focus on finding a fast and practical algorithm that has  approximation guarantees even when m is super constant
